explanation: 1) OS_object_token_t — need the full typedef/struct definition to determine what the parameters actually point to. If OS_object_token_t is a plain struct type then *token_to = *token_from and token_from->lock_mode = ... only modify the objects pointed at (allowed by MISRA). If OS_object_token_t were typedef'd as a pointer type (or contained pointer members) the semantics of the assignment could be different (e.g. copying pointer values) and could imply modification of pointer values rather than just pointed-to objects. Knowing the exact layout also shows whether lock_mode is a member and thus a modification of the pointed-to object. 2) OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE — need the definition (macro/enum/constant) to be sure that the assignment token_from->lock_mode = OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE is an assignment to a member of the pointed-to object (allowed) and not some macro that would expand to something that modifies the parameter itself. Together these symbols let you decide whether any pointer parameter variable is being assigned to (which would violate the MISRA rule) or only the objects they point to (which is permitted).
